awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: High-performance, tunable silicon laser arrays designed for mass production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is demonstrate new lasers for advanced communication and sensing applications.  The proposed work includes the design, simulation, and testing of new lasers to meet rapidly-growing high-speed data center optical communication and emerging automotive laser range-finding requirements. 

The proposed project activities will include the design, simulation, and experimental verification of hybrid, external-cavity silicon-based optical sources to meet rapidly-growing high-speed datacenter optical communication and emerging automotive laser range-finding requirements.  The project will demonstrate that a flexible electronic-photonic integration process can be created to enable dense integration of silicon-photonic and silicon-electronic circuits, independent of specific foundry or fabrication production limitations. This process can be used to develop arrays of high-performance, low-noise, and widely-tunable lasers for advanced optical communication and sensing applications. The proposed project will address existing laser mode-control issues and reduce back-reflection issues.  The result will be silicon-photonic lasers suitable for commercial production that will demonstrate industry-leading semiconductor laser capabilities including low-noise, narrow-linewidth, and wide tunability in single and multi-laser chipsets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Phase I and Phase II programs launched Axalume’s laser development programs, including single-wavelength and tunable lasers suitable for integration with photonic integrated circuits. During the Phase II program we signed a Memorandum of Understanding with a public optical networking company to jointly develop a high-performance, tunable silicon-based laser for optical networking applications. We developed and demonstrated silicon-based tunable laser samples for the widely used C-band (1550nm) wavelength range and integrated electronic drivers together with control software/firmware for testing of the laser module per our partner’s product requirements. We achieved the laser performance specifications and tunability needed, and we packaged several tunable lasers for test and evaluation and delivery.
As part of our Phase II TECP program, we worked closely with our Phase II partner to create the preliminary design of the wideband tunable laser for mass production at a US foundry. The design incorporated the laser cavity including the compound semiconductor gain and silicon photonic sections, the tuning elements, phase-control elements and laser driver and control circuits for the integrated laser based on the commercial foundry chosen by our partner. The results of this first run showed some design changes were needed to be compatible with the foundry processes. We are continuing to refine the critical part of the design to couple the gain chips to the rest of the silicon laser cavity to meet the original foundry requirements and are, in parallel, exploring alternate foundries that we expect will be more suitable for mass production. Our customer has reiterated its commitment to continue our joint development work with the objective of bringing to market a co-integrated narrow-linewidth tunable laser with a silicon photonic transceiver for differentiated high-performance intra-datacenter and inter-datacenter networking.
A separate outcome of our Phase IIb effort is that we are developing optical transceiver products based on quantum-dot lasers for O-band (1300nm) intra-datacenter and AI transceiver applications together with our partner, Innolume GmbH. During our Phase IIB commercialization effort we developed a prototype quantum-dot laser based 800G OSFP transceiver. This was developed and demonstrated at the 2023 Optical Fiber Communication (OFC) conference, the industry’s premier optical fiber optics show. Additional information can be found in [https://www.semiconductor-today.com/news_items/2023/mar/alfalume-060323.shtml]. During the show, we exhibited our prototype transceiver module that consisted of an array of modulators powered by a single quantum-dot laser together with the electronics and fiber-optics. We also developed a reference design and production assembly flow process for the 800G transceiver. After the conference, we observed widespread industry interest in the octal 800G transceiver with quantum dot lasers using silicon photonic modulators to replace LNOI modulators and elimination of the digital signal processing chip to reduce power dissipation and cost. This was one of the highlights of the following year’s (OFC 2024) conference. See [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0qho3gJJRZs] for more information. We continue to pursue this opportunity jointly with our partners. In addition, our Phase IIb transceiver development work has brought to our attention customer interest in a compact, power-efficient optical transceiver with a wide operating temperature range for US markets, exploiting the ability of the quantum-dot lasers to reliably operate up to 125°C.


Last Modified: 01/27/2025
Modified by: Ashok Krishnamoorthy
